You're gonna get chat like this in an online competitive team game. If people dont like it they have the facility to mute.

I mean sure, hate speech?  racism? Homophobia? Support of the liberal party? Punish away. But this hardly falls into those categories. The over reaction is real.

Out of curiosity, are you able to shed any light on why, since about august, Riot have become so highly strung about banter which has existed in this ecosystem since it started? Why all of a sudden is this sort of chat a cardinal sin? 

Its WAY over the top to be chat restricted for this. What changed at your end to make dishing out punishment for very minor infractions like this so common? years of play of this game under my belt but I have never seen punishments dished out with the severity and frequency that they have been in the last few months. What is the go?

Some old reasoning that is still relevant today: When a player has to mute someone, the damage is already done. The person spouting crap does not get their right to spout crap protected just because others can turn it off after they've had enough of it.

You're sure as hell not gonna get chat like this on a basketball court. Why should we accept that it's okay to be a genuine asshole online when it's legitimately not okay in the real world?

The guy who simply can't help but have a whinge or spout abuse/negativity at their teammates on the football field is the guy that doesn't get invited to play next time. Who'd seriously invite that guy?

We'll penalize players more harshly and quickly for abuse like the types you've mentioned, but we'll also still eventually penalize players who consistently fall under categories like "legit kind of a dick" or "man I really don't wanna play with that guy again".

Most players agree with that philosophy, reports made against players like that show as much. We are acting upon those reports.

Poking fun, havin a laugh, issuing a challenge; that's the sort of stuff that is banter as long as you don't escalate any of that into persistent bullying when it's clear the other player is not up for it.
Banter is not "youre a fucking pussy shen", it just isn't.

You were flaming your team for the entire game 1.

>Severity isn't determined where penalties are applied

It is. Serious offences will escalate you tiers. Your log is definitely gross, but like you say you weren't being racist or anything so you were escalated normally through the four tiers (10 game chat, 25 game chat, 14 day ban, perma ban). You got a 10 game chat restriction, showed that it didn't prompt you to be more aware and careful of your behaviour at all, and so continued through the tiers.

I don't know the context of your friend's punishment, so I'm not going to comment on it. I don't want any speculation to be taken out of context. You have to remember though that while you and your friend may be 'bantering', and you seem to have a very loose definition of that if you consider your log to be banter, there are still 3 other people on your team, and 8 in the game that have to listen to you. If you're creating a negative experience for them then that's no bueno.

>but who's to tell it is banter

The players in your game do. The community ultimately decides what is or isn't ok by what they choose to report. If you r team agreed that it was banter, then the game wouldn't have even been looked at. I didnt play basketball, but played indoor soccer for years. Had a guy threaten to smash my face in but when I called him a dickhead and got in his face about it he backed off. Shook hands after the game, played him again in round 9. No more threats to smash my face in (although he did threaten to stab my team mate in a different game). Thing is, it was a game, people got heated, said some things and carried on with the game, shake hands after (except that one time he was a dick about it to another team mate - to be fair that dude on the opposition was a colossal D-hole), 
but honestly it was no big deal.

But I certainly didnt go report him to the ref for saying bad words, and the ref didnt get all up in his beef about it.

But I can tell you right now if the same guy started kicking own goals or letting the opposition through, he would not be welcomed back.

If you play basket ball you know that sometimes things get heated, team mates get frustrated, and fights almost kick off. But it is part of the game and not something to get kicked off the team for if it is all in the spirit of the game.

Thats the problem right now - bad words are the worst possible thing you can do in lol yet behaviour which actually wrecks games but requires manual as opposed to automated reviews does not get punished nearly as frequently.

sticks and stones.

I played field hockey for 10 years and if someone threatened to smash someone's face in they'd be out faster than they could blink. That's the kind of shit that gets you kicked off and blacklisted from teams. Telling someone you're gonna destroy them on the field today is very different from threatening physical violence or just tearing into someone for the whole game, nevermind doing that to your own team. One is banter within the context of the game, the other is a literal threat.

Different backgrounds account for a lot, but surely you realise that most people don't want to be threatened on a regular basis? That people don't want to get into a game just to have someone spout a load of garbage about how bad you are at the game when you either already know you made a mistake or just disagree with how they wanted you to play it, and to continue to berate you for that one mistake for the rest of the game?

I get that muting is a thing, but if someone tries to punch me and I dodge it, does that mean there's no problem with them trying to punch me?

I'd also like you to remember that chat is a lot easier to punish. With gameplay there are a lot more greys than people realise because when you're in the game, it's obvious they're trolling or intent feeding. But it's a whole lot quicker and easier to review a chat log than it is to review a replay of a 20+ minute game. It's less a matter of chat being treated more harshly, and more a matter of chat being punished more efficiently at present. 

Chat is also the kind of thing that people are more likely to argue, because if they get banned for intent feeding, they know exactly what they did, but chat has a lot more perspective to it, and people are far less understanding of other people's perspectives.

the way you talk about sport makes me think you never have played any extensively at a competitive level. you probably play/ed it at a social level where it is generally for fun and to 'be social' as the name suggests. correct me if im wrong but its hard to believe otherwise...

i played basketball up to a state level. you definitely get this kind of chat on the court (you even occasionally get physical violence). you also definitely get teammates that are more negative than others. you know, its called personality. not everyone is the same. yeah you may not find someone pleasant but you deal with it. this is competition, not "making friends". sometimes theres players that really dont like each other. it's the same in ranked league. you're generally not doing it to make friends and 'invite them next time'. 

obviously there are lines, but you shouldn't be getting punished for being unpleasant, just like in real life. i can see how being unpleasant and negative in normals would/should be looked down on more as its more akin to social sport. you're not doing it to be super competitive. you're doing it mainly for casual fun and/or practice.

ranked in league is the only competitive way to play the game the average player has access to. you have to accept that it is perceived and treated differently than normals.

would bet my house that there's all kind of language and 'threats' used between teammates of professional LoL players. they may not say it directly to opponents where riot is watching, but 100% guaranteed they describe some of their opponents as "pussies" and all kinds of names. also 100% guaranteed there are 'negative' players that some teammates have to deal with.

"you're a pussy", "what a bunch of pussies" etc is actually one of the most common banter things said in sport....
